adult: RisperidoneAlternative Names:Risperdal9-OH risperidonePaliperidoneLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:RISPAH for Alfred, RISPO for Outside testsSpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:Lithium Heparin (without Gel)EDTA 3 mL
assay: RisperidoneAlternative Names:Risperdal9-OH risperidonePaliperidoneLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:RISPAH for Alfred, RISPO for Outside testsSpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:Lithium Heparin (without Gel)EDTA 3 mLAdults Volume or Mass:3 mLMinimum/Paediatric Volume or Mass:3 mLTransport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room Temperature
note:
Suggested therapeutic range (20-60 mcg/L) follows the recommendation of the AGNP (1). Similar ranges were confirmed in therapeutic levels that were taken in large numbers of patients (2). Add the sum of risperidone and 9 hydroxy risperidone (active metabolite) to calculate the therapeutic range.  Paliperidone, which is used therapeutically, is 9 hydroxy risperidone.

Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic. It is used to treat schizophrenia, bipolar disorder and irritability associated with autism. Common side effects include extrapyramidal movement disturbances, sleepiness, constipation and increases in weight. There is evidence for relationships between plasma concentrations of the drug and metabolite and effectiveness as well as extrapyramidal side-effects. The metabolite is active and has a longer half life and brackets (24 hours) then risperidone (4 hours). For the therapeutic range add both drug and metabolite together. A low metabolite to parent ratio (normal  4 to 23 with oral medication, 1-4 after i.m. Medication) indicates a different CYP2D6 genotype with poor metabolism. Fluoxetine inhibits CYP2D6 and increases risperidone concentrations.


	Hiemke C, et al. Consensus Guidelines for Therapeutic Drug Monitoring in Neuropsychopharmacology: Update 2017 [published correction appears in Pharmacopsychiatry. 2018 Jan;51(1-02):e1]. Pharmacopsychiatry. 2018;51(1-02):9–62. Doi:10.1055/s-0043-116492
	Jönsson AK, et al. Compilation of Serum Concentrations of 12 Antipsychotic Drugs in a Therapeutic Drug Monitoring Setting. Ther Drug Monit. 2019;41(3):348–356. doi:10.1097/FTD.00000000000005852.

row:
RisperidoneAlternative Names:Risperdal9-OH risperidonePaliperidoneLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:RISPAH for Alfred, RISPO for Outside testsSpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:Lithium Heparin (without Gel)EDTA 3 mLAdults Volume or Mass:3 mLMinimum/Paediatric Volume or Mass:3 mLTransport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAssay Frequency:WeeklyAdditional Notes:Suggested therapeutic range (20-60 mcg/L) follows the recommendation of the AGNP (1). Similar ranges were confirmed in therapeutic levels that were taken in large numbers of patients (2). Add the sum of risperidone and 9 hydroxy risperidone (active metabolite) to calculate the therapeutic range.  Paliperidone, which is used therapeutically, is 9 hydroxy risperidone.

Risperidone is an atypical antipsychotic. It is used to treat schizophrenia, bipolar disorder and irritability associated with autism. Common side effects include extrapyramidal movement disturbances, sleepiness, constipation and increases in weight. There is evidence for relationships between plasma concentrations of the drug and metabolite and effectiveness as well as extrapyramidal side-effects. The metabolite is active and has a longer half life and brackets (24 hours) then risperidone (4 hours). For the therapeutic range add both drug and metabolite together. A low metabolite to parent ratio (normal  4 to 23 with oral medication, 1-4 after i.m. Medication) indicates a different CYP2D6 genotype with poor metabolism. Fluoxetine inhibits CYP2D6 and increases risperidone concentrations.


	Hiemke C, et al. Consensus Guidelines for Therapeutic Drug Monitoring in Neuropsychopharmacology: Update 2017 [published correction appears in Pharmacopsychiatry. 2018 Jan;51(1-02):e1]. Pharmacopsychiatry. 2018;51(1-02):9–62. Doi:10.1055/s-0043-116492
	Jönsson AK, et al. Compilation of Serum Concentrations of 12 Antipsychotic Drugs in a Therapeutic Drug Monitoring Setting. Ther Drug Monit. 2019;41(3):348–356. doi:10.1097/FTD.00000000000005852.

assay: ClozapineLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:CLOZAH for Alfred, CLOZO for Outside testsSpecimen Types:PlasmaSerumContainer Types:Lithium Heparin (without Gel)EDTA 3 mLPlain tube - serum  (no Gel)Adults Volume or Mass:2 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Collect pre-doseTransport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room Temperature
collection: Collect pre-dose
container: Lithium Heparin (without Gel)EDTA 3 mLPlain tube - serum  (no Gel)
note:
Evidence suggests that clozapine plasma levels of at least 250-350 mcg/L are required for optimal clinical response.

Our recommended therapeutic range (Clozapine levels 350-600 mcg/L) follows the consensus guidelines published in psychopharmacology in 2018 (1). Only about 1/3 of patients show drug levels within that range. Some patients will require higher clozapine concentrations of up to 800 mcg/L for disease control without increased levels of side effects.

Hiemke C, et al. Consensus Guidelines for Therapeutic Drug Monitoring in Neuropsychopharmacology: Update 2017. Pharmacopsychiatry. 2018 Jan;51(1-02):e1. doi: 10.1055/s-0037-1600991. Epub 2018 Feb 1.

collection: Department Head authorisation required (except Neurology patients).
external: CJD Registry
note:
Notes:

(i)        The 14-3-3 protein is a non-specific marker of central nervous system neuronal injury or death. Based on international experience in carefully selected patient, a positive result has approximately 90% sensitivity and specificity for sporadic CJD. “False” positives are frequently recognised in encephalitis (especially Herpes Simplex) and recent cerebral infarcts.

(ii)   If the sample is haemorrhagic, a false positive result is likely. It is recommended that a repeat sample is submitted after 10 to 14 days.

(i)        The 14-3-3 protein is a non-specific marker of central nervous system neuronal injury or death. Based on international experience in carefully selected patient, a positive result has approximately 90% sensitivity and specificity for sporadic CJD. “False” positives are frequently recognised in encephalitis (especially Herpes Simplex) and recent cerebral infarcts.

(ii)   If the sample is haemorrhagic, a false positive result is likely. It is recommended that a repeat sample is submitted after 10 to 14 days.

assay:
Chromium PlasmaAlternative Names:Plasma ChromiumLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:CRPLSpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:Metal-Free EDTACollection & Request Instructions:For monitoring occupational exposure not nutritional deficiency.

 

To limit the possibility of contamination, the first collected tube should not be used for Chromium. If no other tubes need to be collected please collect 2 tubes and discard first collected.  High concentrations of Gadolinium and Iodine are known to interfere with most metals tests.  If either Gadolinium-  or Iodine- containing contrast media has been administered, a specimen should not be collected for at least 96 hours.

This collection can be shared with Cobalt.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room Temperature
collection:
For monitoring occupational exposure not nutritional deficiency.

 

To limit the possibility of contamination, the first collected tube should not be used for Chromium. If no other tubes need to be collected please collect 2 tubes and discard first collected.  High concentrations of Gadolinium and Iodine are known to interfere with most metals tests.  If either Gadolinium-  or Iodine- containing contrast media has been administered, a specimen should not be collected for at least 96 hours.

This collection can be shared with Cobalt.
container: Chromium PlasmaAlternative Names:Plasma ChromiumLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:CRPLSpecimen Types:Plasma
note:
Plasma Chromium Reference Interval:

<26 nmol/L

Prosthesis wear is known to result in increased circulating concentration of metal ions. Modest increase (6 - 12 nmol/L) in serum Cr concentration is likely to be associated with a prosthetic device in good condition. Serum concentrations >19 nmol/L in a patient with Cr-based implant suggest significant prosthesis wear. Increased serum trace element concentrations in the absence of corroborating clinical information do not independently predict prosthesis wear or failure. (Source: Mayo Clinic, accessed 22/9/15)

collection:
Samples are collected either as a core or wedge biopsy. The sample may be stored dry in a suitable polystyrene container at freezer temps(-20)

or may be fixed with formalin and stored at room temp.

Samples may also be delivered embedded in paraffin.

10 mm core biopsy preferred

Method: ICP-MS

collection: Collect on Ice
container: Vitamin ALaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:VIT ASpecimen Types:Serum
note:
Reference Range:
Adult:  1.0—2.8 umol/L
1 - 6 y.o:  0.7—1.5 umol/L
Vitamin A is measured as retinol by HPLC-UV. Retinol levels below 0.7 umol/L are diagnostic of Vitamin A deficiency, while levels of  0.7—1.0 umol/L are borderline deficient. Retinol levels above 2.6 umol/L have been associated with an increased risk of fracture (N Engl J Med 348:287-294, 2003).

assay: Vitamin CAlternative Names:Ascorbic AcidLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:VITCSpecimen Types:PlasmaSerumContainer Types:Lithium Heparin (with Gel)SSTAdults Volume or Mass:1 mLMinimum/Paediatric Volume or Mass:1 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Ascorbic acid levels reduced in deficiency. The specific therapeutic use for Vitamin C is the prophylaxis and treatment of scurvy. Whether Vitamin C deficiency has a causal relationship to clinical syndromes other than scurvy has not been established.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Protect from LightSend to lab immediately
collection: Ascorbic acid levels reduced in deficiency. The specific therapeutic use for Vitamin C is the prophylaxis and treatment of scurvy. Whether Vitamin C deficiency has a causal relationship to clinical syndromes other than scurvy has not been established.
note:
Reference interval:

Vitamin C 23 – 85 umol/L

Source:  Chromsystems kit insert (IM 65065 Vitamin C EN 07/2015 R1).

                                                                                                                                   

Vitamin C <11 umol/L . Severe vitamin C deficiency.  These levels are typically associated with increased rates of scurvy.             

                               

Vitamin C levels  11 - 23 umol/L           

Marginal vitamin C deficiency.  Increased levels of Ischemic heart disease and mortality have been described in population based long term follow up studies.  Lykkesfeldt J, Poulsen HE.  Is vitamin C supplementation beneficial?  Lessons learned from randomised controlled trials. Br J Nutr. 2010 May; 103(9):1251-9. doi: 10.1017/S0007114509993229.

collection: Collect on IceIf collecting for BOTH Vitamin A and E - a Serum (SST) tube MUST be collected on ICE.
container: Vitamin ELaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:VIT ESpecimen Types:SerumPlasma
note:
Reference Range :
Adult (>12yrs):  12 - 42 umol/L
< 12 y.o :               7 - 21 umol/L
Vitamin E is highly lipid soluble and levels should be corrected for lipid levels (Suggest: Ratio of Vitamin E (in umol/L) divided by the sum of Cholesterol and Triglycerides (in mmol/L). A Ratio of greater than or equal to 1.59 is considered normal. Eur J Nutr 43: 86 - 92, 2004). Increasing levels are seen with age.

collection:
Patient must be on a diet of 70—100 g fat/day for at least 4 days prior and during the period of collection.

72 hour collection of faeces in special metal containers obtained from Pathology. It is preferred that the whole 72 hour collection be sent in the one container. If more than one is used, a separate request form, with the collection period stated, must accompany each container
note:
This assay is no longer available

Consult Chemical Pathologist for further information.

For an adult, a faecal weight of < 200 g/72 hours is not consistent with malabsorption and the assay will not then be performed with consultation.

Note: In paediatric samples a microscopic analyis of fat globules may be of value in a spot sample- consult chemical pathologist/registrar.

assay: Testosterone FreeAlternative Names:Free TestosteroneLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:FRTESpecimen Types:SerumContainer Types:SSTTransport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:n/a
container: Testosterone FreeAlternative Names:Free TestosteroneLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:FRTESpecimen Types:Serum
note:
Reference Interval:

Adult Males:   260 -740 pmol/L

Adult Female: 3-37 pmol/L

Male Comment:

Free testosterone calculated using the Vermeulen equation (Ann Clin Biochem 2006; 43:389-397)

This reference interval is based on the study from Andrology Australia in eugonadal young men (Sikaris KA et al, J Clin Endocrinol Metab 2005; 90:5928-36.) There is an age related fall in free testosterone in healthy older men, whose calculated free testosterone may be as low as 140pmol/L.

Clinical correlation is required for interpretation of results

 

Female Comment:

Free testosterone calculated using the Vermeulen equation (Ann Clin Biochem 2006; 43:389-397)

This reference interval is based published data (Davison SL et al. JCEM  2005 Jul;90(7):3847-53.

Clinical correlation is required for interpretation of results

container: Lithium Heparin (without Gel)EDTA 3 mLPlain tube - serum  (no Gel)
note:
We recommend a therapeutic range of 20 to 40 mcg/L based on the review by Bishara et al. (1). The half-life of the drug is 30 to 60 hours and measurement should occur at the earliest one week after starting therapy. Most patients will achieve therapeutic levels with doses of 10 to 15 mg per day. There are variations of drug levels with sex (women have higher levels for the same dose) age (younger and older patients might have higher concentrations) and smoking (smokers have lower levels).

Olanzapine is an atypical antipsychotic drug helpful in the treatment of schizophrenia, mania and related agitation. It is an effective antipsychotic drug with relatively low risk of upper middle symptoms and hyperprolactinaemia, but has been associated with weight gain and hypoglycaemia. Most patients achieve therapeutic plasma levels with doses of 10-15 mg/d. Olanzapine has a half-live of 30-60 hours and it takes about seven days to achieve steady-state. There is extensive metabolism of olanzapine by the cytochrome P-450 enzyme family (CYP1A2, CYP2D6, CYP3A4. Further metabolism is by the flavin containing monooxygenase and via glucuronidation. Metabolites are clinically not active. There is no universally agreed therapeutic range and the evidence that higher concentrations are associated with a better response is missing. Based on data showing optimal dopamine receptor occupation with plasma concentrations of 20- 40 mg/L (1) we adopt these recommendations rather than the higher suggested therapeutic ranges of the Arbeitsgemeinschaft fur Neuropsychopharmakologie und Pharmakopsychiatrie (AGNP) (2).

1. Bishara et al. Olanzapine: A Systematic Review and Meta-Regression of the Relationships Between Dose, Plasma Concentration, Receptor Occupancy, and Response. J Clin Psychopharmacol 2013;33: 329-335

2. Hiemke C, et al. Consensus Guidelines for Therapeutic Drug Monitoring in Neuropsychopharmacology: Update 2017 [published correction appears in Pharmacopsychiatry. 2018 Jan;51(1-02):e1]. Pharmacopsychiatry. 2018;51(1-02):9–62. doi:10.1055/s-0043-116492

collection:
For identification of carriers of inherited venous thrombophilia. General population screening and routine screening before prescribing oral contraceptives or hormone replacement therapy are not recommended. test should only be requested by a practioner skilled in genetic counselling of thrombophilia. The significance of a polymorphism in an affected individual is uncertain. Test is Methyl Tetrahydrofolate Reductase C677T.

 

 Homozygous mutation may be associated with increased thrombotic risk.

note:
Assay performed on Roche Elecsys (ECLIA)

Reference Range : <115 IU/ml

Note: Thyroglobulin concentrations > 2000 ug/L may lead to falsely elevated anti-Thyroglobulin concentrations.

Note: Biotin supplementation may cause falsely high results due to interference with the anti TG Ab assay. If this patient is known to be taking Biotin, interpret results with caution and contact the Chemical Pathologist (03) 90763118 if further discussion is required.

Test: Total Haemolytic ComplementAlternative Names:Haemolytic Complement; TotalCH100CH50classical pathwayAH50Alternate pathwayMannose pathway
collection:
Collect at ambient temperatureSamples should be processed as “urgent” as Functional complement tests have precise collection requirements to ensure accurate and reproducible results.Plasma, heat inactivated serum or sera with pronounced hemolysis, icterus, lipemia or microbial growth are not suitable for testing and will not be processed

Collect 3 ml of whole blood into plain gel-free (neutral) serum tube- time critical - take to lab for processing of sample.
external: Women's and Children's Pathology Services, RCH
note:
Very time dependent collection and processing required- 3 ml of whole blood into plain gel-free (neutral) serum tube required.

Take immediately to pathology and label as urgent

note:
Reference Interval (Adults 19 yrs +):   

2.10—2.60 mmol/L

Source:

RCPA/AACB Harmonised Reference Intervals from 13/7/2015.

Serum total calcium rises or falls approximately
0.018 mmol/L for each g/L change in serum albumin.

Corrected calcium (CCA) will be automatically calculated when serum albumin is also requested.

CCA = Calcium Lvl+(40-Albumin Lvl)*0.018

Age Related Reference Intervals:

< 1 yrs                     2.13- 2.75 mmol/L

1 yr - < 19 yrs      2.3-2.63 mmol/L

collection:
In cases where prolonged apnoea follows suxamethonium administration an assessment of atypical cholinesterase can be made using the Dibucaine and Fluoride Numbers. Such assessment should not be made until 24 hours after suxamethonium administration.

Avoid haemolysis.

Note Additional Collection Instructions:

Pathology Queensland prefer to receive BOTH a SST or Lithium Heparin Plasma specimen PLUS a 4 mL EDTA whole blood sample.(EDTA specimen must be sent unspun).

container: Histamine UrineAlternative Names:Methyl-Histamine UrineLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:UMEHITSpecimen Types:Urine 24 hour
external: The Children's Hospital at Westmead
note:
SPECIAL DIET

Urinary Catecholamine, Histamine & 5-HIAA Estimation 

This special diet was designed by the Departments of Clinical Biochemistry and Nutrition and Dietetics and is suitable for both adults and children having urine collected for catecholamines, histamine or serotonin studies.

The diet must be followed for 24 hours prior to and also during the course of urine collection. 

Avoid the following: 

Fruit: Bananas, canned and fresh pineapple, plum, grapes, kiwifruit, avocado, cherries, blueberries, raspberries, strawberries, blackcurrants, oranges, guava, mango, passionfruit, dried fruit.

Jams:All except apricot.

Vegetables:Tomatoes, mushrooms, spinach, broccoli, brussel sprouts, cauliflower, eggplant, broadbeans, pickled vegetables eg sauerkraut.

Nuts & Seeds: All including peanut butter and tahini

Dairy: All cheeses and cheese spreads, yoghurt flavoured with nuts, muesli containing nuts or above fruits, chocolate yogo, banana strawberry and chocolate flavoured milk, fruit smoothies.

Fish & Seafood: All including canned, fried and salted fish and seafood.

Chocolate:All forms including Cocoa and Milo.

Processed Meats: All including devon, salami, sausages, ham, chicken loaf, turkey loaf.

Condiments: All chutneys and also malted or coloured vinegar, mayonnaise & tartare sauce.

Fermented Foods: Yeast extracts eg Marmite, Vegemite, fish paste, fish sauce, soy sauce, meat gravy.

Drinks: All wine and beer (all fermented beverages). Juices of all fruit listed above.

 

The following foods are allowed: 

Rice: Brown or white, rice cakes – avoid any rice product containing nuts, seeds, fruit or flavouring as listed above.

Bread & Cereals: All plain bread and breakfast cereals, whole meal and white flour products except those containing nuts, seeds, fruit, flavourings or fillings as listed above.

Pasta: Including spaghetti or noodles. Avoid those containing nuts, seeds, fruit, flavouring or fillings as listed above eg. Avoid ravioli and coloured pastas.

Confectionery :Brown or white sugar. Boiled and jelly sweets.

Fresh fruit: Apples, pears, apricots, peaches, rockmelon, watermelon.

Vegetables: All fresh vegetables not listed above.

Coconut: Including coconut milk.

Dairy: Fresh milk, fresh cream, vanilla yoghurt, plain ice cream and custard, (artificial) strawberry yogo.

Meats: All freshly prepared meats, including chicken.

Eggs: Whole eggs, egg white and yolk are allowed.

Spreads: Apricot jam and honey.

Condiments: Clear vinegar, vanilla, nutmeg, powdered stock (eg for gravy) may be used only if freshly prepared.

Drinks: Milk, milkshakes (vanilla, coffee, plain or caramel flavoured), lemonade, tea, coffee, apple juice.

 

Information sheet from The Children's Hospital at Westmead

https://www.slhd.nsw.gov.au/sswps/fact%20sheets/Sheet%2044.pdf

assay:
OsteocalcinLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:OSTEOCALCSpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:EDTA 3 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Avoid hemolysis. Erythrocytes contain proteases which degrade Osteocalcin.  Centrifuge specimens immediately.

EDTA plasma preferred specimen for analysis.

EDTA plasma samples stable 2 days at 15-25C, 3 days at 2-8C, 3 mths at -20C. Feeze only once.

 

Serum levels reflect the extent of laying down of bone matrix. Useful in monitoring when this is affected by disease or drug therapy.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room Temperature

collection:
Dietary restriction or special diet.Foods containing appreciable amounts of collagen should be avoided in the 24 hrs prior to specimen collection. These foods include meats an meat products, gravy and even confectionary and ice-cream containing gelatin.

The patient fasts from 8pm on the night before collection. On waking the bladdder is voided and urine discarded. The next urine is collected 1-2 hours later at which time breakfast may be eaten.

Dietary restriction or special diet.Role in the diagnosis of Carcinoid Syndrome

Clinical Staff should ensure that patients have an appropriate diet during the urine collection; no phenothiazines or serotonin-containing foods should be consumed.( eg bananas, pineapples, red plums, walnuts, avocadoes, eggplant or tomatoes).

collection:
Melbourne Health Pathology(RMH) perfoms 5FC testing on Tuesday and Thursdays.

Cut-off time for RMH to receive the 5FC samples for analysis is 1200 hrs.
external: Melbourne Health Shared Pathology Service
note:
5 FC Therapeutic range:

Mean steady-state levels of 35-70 mg/L recommended for effective antifungal therapy.  Levels >100 mg/L may be associated with bone marrow toxicity.

If Trough and Peak levels are measured- aim for a trough level of 25-50 mg/L and peak 30-80 mg/L

assay: FluconazoleLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:FLUCOSpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:EDTA 10 mLAdults Volume or Mass:3 mLMinimum/Paediatric Volume or Mass:3 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Collect at steady state:Trough sampleTransport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room Temperature
collection: Collect at steady state:Trough sample
note:
A clear-cut therapeutic range has not been described. British guidelines (1) suggest the use of area under the curve (AUC- estimated from measurements at 1, 4 and 24 hours) over the minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC) of the organism and that >100 using the EUCAST method is associated with higher treatment success. A Brazilian study published recently describes serum levels between 20 and 40 mg/L in patients with neurocryptococcosis and that CSF levels correlate with serum levels. (2) Others (European Conference on Infections in Leukemia) suggest trough levels of > 10-15 mg/L as an alternative (see http://www.ecil-leukaemia.com/telechargements2015/ECIL6-Triazole-TDM-07-12-2015-Lewis-R-et-al.pdf ).

 

1. Ashbee HR et al. Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) of Antifungal Agents: Guidelines From the British Society for Medical Mycology. J Antimicrob Chemother. 2014 May;69(5):1162-76.  doi: 10.1093/jac/dkt508.  Epub 2013 Dec 29. 

2.Schiave LA, et al. Fluconazole levels in serum and cerebrospinal fluid according to daily dosage in patients with cryptococcosis and other fungal infections.  Braz J Infect Dis. 2018 Jan-Feb;22(1):11-15. doi: 10.1016/j.bjid.2017.10.003. Epub 2017 Nov 13.

British guidelines (1) suggest the use of area under the curve (AUC- estimated from measurements at 1, 4 and 24 hours) over the minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC) of the organism and that >100 using the EUCAST method is associated with higher treatment success. A Brazilian study published recently describes serum levels between 20 and 40 mg/L in patients with neurocryptococcosis and that CSF levels correlate with serum levels. (2) Others (European Conference on Infections in Leukemia) suggest trough levels of > 10-15 mg/L as an alternative (see http://www.ecil-leukaemia.com/telechargements2015/ECIL6-Triazole-TDM-07-12-2015-Lewis-R-et-al.pdf ).

 

1. Ashbee HR et al. Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) of Antifungal Agents: Guidelines From the British Society for Medical Mycology. J Antimicrob Chemother. 2014 May;69(5):1162-76.  doi: 10.1093/jac/dkt508.  Epub 2013 Dec 29. 

2.Schiave LA, et al. Fluconazole levels in serum and cerebrospinal fluid according to daily dosage in patients with cryptococcosis and other fungal infections.  Braz J Infect Dis. 2018 Jan-Feb;22(1):11-15. doi: 10.1016/j.bjid.2017.10.003. Epub 2017 Nov 13.

collection: Collect pre-dose
external: Austin Pathology
note:
Pre-Dose - Pre-Dose sampling is useful for checking patient compliance or suspected toxicity. A universal reference range is not applicable.  Correlation between Pre-dose plasma levels of total MPA and clinical outcome depend on the specific clinical setting/patient population and have not been firmly established in some settings.

 

Mycophenolic acid (MPA) total, estimation of AUC 0-12 hr - plasma.

Estimation of AUC 0-12 hr uses a limited sampling approach.  It requires 4 samples (Pre-dose, +1hr, +2 hr, +4hr post dose).

FORMS to be COMPLETED and sent to lab with the samples.

To ensure capture of all data a completed copy of the specific form -downloadable from www.austinpathology.org.au/test-directory      MUST be sent to the lab with the samples for the MPAAUC tests.

A reference range is currently being established. In renal and cardiac transplant recipients an AUC 0-12 hr of 30 to 60 mg.hr/L in the initial phase after transplantation has been shown to associate with less rejection (see Elbarbry FA and Shoker AS, 2007, Clin. Biochem 40:752 for review).

For further information please contact Andrew Ellis, Clinical    Pharmacology and Therapeutics Unit, Austin Pathology on 94963220.

Chemical Pathologist/Registrar approval required - to ensure all forms completed and samples (AUC) collated - prior to sending to Austin Pathology

assay:
PosaconazoleLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:POSASpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:EDTA 10 mLAdults Volume or Mass:5 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Collect pre-doseCollect samples Pre Dose

Do not use tubes with gel separator.
collection:
Collect pre-doseCollect samples Pre Dose

Do not use tubes with gel separator.

Assay run 3 x weekly  (Monday, Tuesday & Thursday) - samples must be in lab by 11AM on each day.                               Results available at end of the day.
note:
Therapeutic Ranges for Posaconazole

 We suggest to monitor Posaconazole trough concentration at steady state (7 days after starting therapy). Levels ≥ 0.7 mg/L are required for prophylaxis and ≥ 1mg/L for invasive fungal infection. 

Reference Interval Source:

Chau M, Kong D, van Hal J et al. Consensus guidelines for optimising antifungal drug delivery and monitoring to avoid toxicity and improve outcomes in patients with haematological malignancy, 2014. Internal Medicine Journal 2014; 1364-1388.

Refer to Alfred PROMPT Posaconazole guideline for further details

collection:
Samples are collected either as a core or wedge biopsy. The sample may be stored dry in a suitable polystyrene container at freezer temps(-20)

or may be fixed with formalin and stored at room temp.

Samples may also be delivered embedded in paraffin.

10 mm core biopsy preferred

Test: TPMT Phenotype+/- GenotypeAlternative Names:Thiopurine Methyl Transferase
collection: Used for the identification of patients at risk of myelosuppression prior to initiation of thiopurine drug therapy (e.g. azothioprine, 6-mercaptopurine, thioguanine). We are now sending TPMT tests to PathWest (QEII Medical Centre, WA) who offer a comprehensive, sequential TPMT testing service. TPMT Phenotype, which measures thiopurine methyltransferase activity, is the first-line test and if it is normal no further testing is indicated. If TPMT Phenotype is abnormal, it is automatically followed by the TPMT Genotype test which screens for the common TPMT mutations. There are rare mutations not detected by this Genotype test. An abnormal Phenotype which is not associated with common mutations will prompt sequencing of the entire coding region of the TPMT gene to detect rare mutations.
container: TPMT Phenotype+/- GenotypeAlternative Names:Thiopurine Methyl TransferaseLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:TPMTSpecimen Types:Blood

assay: VoriconazoleLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:VORISpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:EDTA 10 mLAdults Volume or Mass:5 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Collect pre-dose
collection: Collect pre-doseAssay run 3 x weekly  (Monday, Tuesday & Thursday) - samples must be in lab by 11AM on each day.                               Results available at the end of the day.
note:
Therapeutic Range for Voriconazole

Monitoring Voriconazole trough concentration at steady state (after one week of initiation or change of therapy) can be clinically helpful. 

Suggested therapeutic range is: 1 - 5.5 mg/L.  Trough concentrations < 1 mg/L suggest inappropriate absorption and concentrations > 5.5 mg/L have been associated with toxicity.

(Dodds Ashley E and Perfect JR. Pharmacology of Azoles. UpToDate (accessed online 12/7/10)

Refer to Alfred PROMPT Voriconazole guideline for further details

container: ACTHAlternative Names:AdrenoCorticoTrophic HormoneLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:ACTHSpecimen Types:Plasma
note:
Method used is Roche Elecsys (ECLIA).

Reference Range:  5—60 ng/L

Note: Biotin supplementation may cause falsely low results due to interference with the ACTH assay. If the patient is known to be taking Biotin, interpret results with caution and contact the Chemical Pathologist (03) 90763118 if further discussion is required.

collection:
Add exactly 2.7 mL of blood & mix by inversion.Deliver to laboratory within 60 minutes
A pre–dose level should be measured when the creatinine clearance is known or estimated to be below 0.5 mL/sec. If the pre–dose level is at the higher end or above the reference range, please discuss with the Haematologist (Ext. 63075). Must provide details of anticoagulant in use. Mark request as "Priority"
.
Specimens cannot be analysed or re-analysed greater than 2 hours after collection.
.When the collection is by vacuum tube,the coagulation tube should be collected second to avoid artefactual shortening of coagulation assays due to the trauma of venesection.  When syringes are used, have ready two plastic syringes. A butterfly needle may be used. Withdraw 5 mL blood into the first syringe and discard the syringe (or use it for other tests). With the second syringe, withdraw the required amount of blood for the coagulation tests. When blood is collected from an arterial line it is necessary to discard the first 20mL of blood to clear any heparin from the line before collecting the blood for coagulation tests.
note: Reference Range: 0.50—1.00 IU/mL

A butterfly needle may be used. Withdraw 5 mL blood into the first syringe and discard the syringe (or use it for other tests). With the second syringe, withdraw the required amount of blood for the coagulation tests. When blood is collected from an arterial line it is necessary to discard the first 20mL of blood to clear any heparin from the line before collecting the blood for coagulation tests.
note: Reference Range: Target anti-Xa level 0.5-0.8 units/ml

B12 results should be interpreted in the clinical context and in the light of other results available; e.g. FBE and Blood Film.

Only a minority of patients with B12 levels between 130-250 pmol/L will exhibit true deficiency.

A normal value does not exclude deficiency if there is a high index of suspicion clinically.

collection: Ca 19-9 should only be used for follow up of patients with histologically proven tumour and not for screening for cancer. Ca 19-9 is elevated in most pancreatic adenocarcinomas, around 50% of gastric carcinomas and 30% of colorectal carcinomas. The main function of Ca 19-9 measurement is surveillance and monitoring of therapy in patients with known pancreatic adenocarcinoma. ASCO guidelines suggest that an elevation of Ca 19-9 levels alone is insufficient for diagnosis of recurrence, and confirmation with imaging studies +/- biopsy is required.It may also be elevated in a number of benign conditions including pancreatitis and cirrhosis.
note:
Reference Interval:

  96% of healthy subjects have CA 19-9 levels  <37 kU/L

Method used is Abbott Alinity (CMIA).


Reformulation of Ca 19-9 assay as of 1st October 2014. No clinically significant change in result expected. Reference Interval unchanged, please contact lab if there are any concerns.

collection:
Ca-125 should only be used for follow up of patients with histologically proven tumour and not for screening for cancer. Ca-125 is currently the best serum marker for epithelial ovarian cancer and helpful in the followup and monitoring of these patients..

Indications for measurement of Ca-125 include:


	Staging of newly diagnosed disease
	Surveillance for recurrent disease after curative treatment
	Monitoring of response of disease to treatment


Ca 125 levels may also be elevated in a variety of situations where the peritoneal epithelium is irritated, such as ascites and are therefore not diagnostic of ovarian cancer.
note:
Reference Range:  <35 kU/L

Method used is Abbott Alinity (CMIA).

collection:
CEA should only be used for follow up of patients with histologically proven tumour and not for screening for cancer. CEA can be elevated in almost any advanced adenocarcinoma but is rarely elevated in localised cancer. It is elevated in a number of non-malignant conditions including chronic liver disease, Crohn’s disease, renal disease, emphysema and in healthy smokers.

Possible clinical indications for measurement are:


	Preoperatively to provide prognostic information, and to assess utility for postoperative surveillance.
	Surveillance following curative resection of colorectal cancer.
	Monitoring therapy for advanced colorectal cancer.


However, there is little evidence that monitoring patients leads to improved outcomes or improved quality of life.

collection:
CK should be used only in the early stages of myocardial infarction. If the CK is normal shortly after onset of chest pain thought to be of myocardial origin then a repeat estimation 3—4 hours later may be helpful.
CK is less sensitive and less specific for the diagnosis of myocardial injury than Troponin I. Skeletal muscle CK is elevated in several situations, e.g. post–operatively, after intramuscular injections, following trauma or vigorous exercise, and in some diseases of skeletal muscle.

assay:
CreatinineLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:CRSpecimen Types:SerumPlasmaContainer Types:SSTLithium Heparin (with Gel)Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAdditional Notes:Reference Intervals (Adult 19yrs+):

Male:       60—110  umol/L
Female:   45—90   umol/L

Source:

RCPA/AACB Harmonised Reference Intervals from 13/7/2015.

Falsely high creatinine values may be obtained in therapy with ascorbic acid and in the presence of ketones, alpha–methyldopa, haemolysis or high glucose concentrations.

Cephalosporins in high concentration also give falsely high serum creatinine. Blood samples for creatinine should not be taken within one hour of i.v. Cephalosporin administration.
note:
Reference Intervals (Adult 19yrs+):

Male:       60—110  umol/L
Female:   45—90   umol/L

Source:

RCPA/AACB Harmonised Reference Intervals from 13/7/2015.

Falsely high creatinine values may be obtained in therapy with ascorbic acid and in the presence of ketones, alpha–methyldopa, haemolysis or high glucose concentrations.

Cephalosporins in high concentration also give falsely high serum creatinine. Blood samples for creatinine should not be taken within one hour of i.v. Cephalosporin administration.

Assay methods are affected differently by interferences. Where necessary to resolve discrepancies, an enzymatic method is available after consultation.

assay:
C-TelopeptideAlternative Names:CTXLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:CTXSpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:EDTA 6 mLSSTCollection & Request Instructions:Collect in amFasting SampleMarker of bone resorption. Useful for monitoring the effect of anti-resorptive therapy and patient compliance.

Plasma EDTA is the preferred sample as it is stable longer than serum.

Stability of K2- and K3-EDTA plasma: 24 hrs at 20-25C, 8 days at 2-8C

3 months at -20C. For longer periods store at -70C. Freeze only ONCE.

Serum is only stable 6 hrs at 20-25 C, 8 hrs at 4 - 8C,         3 months at -20C. For longer periods store at -70C. Freeze only ONCE

Haemolyzed samples (Hb> 0.5 g/dL) elicit a decrease in the C-Telopeptide (Beta- crosslaps) concentration.

 Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Send to lab immediatelyUse Esky from SDMH or CGMC to AlfredFor external sites transport to Alfred Pathology  Frozen.

Reference Interval Sources:

1) Wyness S et al. Clinica Chimica Acta 2013; 169-172.

2) Vasikaran S, Chubb P, Schneider HG. Towards optimising the provision of laboratory services for bone turnover markers. Pathology 2014; 46(4):267-273.

Assay performed on Roche Elecsys (ECLIA)

Note: Biotin supplementation may cause falsely low results due to interference with the C-Telopeptide assay. If the patient is known to be taking Biotin, interpret results with caution and contact the Chemical Pathologist (03) 90763118 if further discussion is required.

collection: This test is only performed for clinical reasons and the results supplied cannot be used for medico–legal purposes. Samples taken in the Emergency Department in relation to the law applying to motor car accidents are not analysed by the Alfred Pathology Service. All queries regarding these samples should be directed to the Secretary or Director, Emergency Department (Ext. 62138).
note:
Results are reported in mmol/L. Conversion to old units is—  mmol/l x 0.0046 = g/dL
i.e. 10 mmol/L is approximately 0.05 g/dL or 0.05%

collection:
Specimens cannot be analysed or re-analysed greater than 2 hours after collection.
When the collection is by vacuum tube,the coagulation tube should be collected second to avoid artefactual shortening of coagulation assays due to the trauma of venesection.  When syringes are used, have ready two plastic syringes. A butterfly needle may be used. Withdraw 5 mL blood into the first syringe and discard the syringe (or use it for other tests). With the second syringe, withdraw the required amount of blood for the coagulation tests. When blood is collected from an arterial line it is necessary to discard the first 20mL of blood to clear any heparin from the line before collecting the blood for coagulation tests.

Test: Free Light ChainsAlternative Names:Light Chains Free
collection: Useful for the diagnosis and subsequent monitoring of non-secretory myeloma, light chain deposition disease and primary amyloidosis where serum and urine protein electrophoresis are negative.
container: Free Light ChainsAlternative Names:Light Chains FreeLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:FLCSpecimen Types:Serum
note:
Reference Intervals:
Free Kappa:                  3.3—19.4 mg/L
Free lambda:                5.71—26.3 mg/L
Kappa/Lambda ratio:  0.26—1.65

(In patients with renal failure, with no evidence of monoclonal proteins, a ratio of 0.37–3.1* can be used.)

*Hutchison C.A, et al. Serum free light chain measurement aids the diagnosis of myeloma in patients with severe renal failure. BMC Nephrology 2008; 9:11 doi: 10.1186/1471-2369-9-11

 

Elevated free kappa and/or lambda accompanied by a normal kappa/lambda ratio can be due to polyclonal activation or renal failure and should be interpreted with caution.

Long term studies of patients with MGUS and smoldering myeloma have shown a high biological variability of free light chain levels (CV 27.8%) in patients with stable disease (Katzmann et al. Clin Chem 2011: 1687-1692). Clinicians should take this into account when interpreting free light  chain levels in their patients.

Method: The Binding Site OPTILITE (Turbidimetry) from 28/6/2021

  Abnormal:  < 8%

Method used is Abbott Alinity (CMIA).

  < 1 U/L        Not consistent with pregnancy

(Higher levels up to 14 U/L have been reported in non-pregnant women > 40 yrs; see Clin Biochem. 2017 Mar;50(4-5):234-237).

Abbott does not recommend use of the Alinity Total β-hCG assay as a tumour marker. Further information on the performance of different assays for this indication in (Ferraro S, Trevisiol C, Gion M, Panteghini M. Human Chorionic Gonadotropin

collection:
The transcobalamin-vitamin B12 complex (Holotranscobalamin) contains the biologically active cobalamin. A decrease of Holotranscobalamin is one of the earliest markers of cobalamin deficiency.

Retrospective testing - Note Sample MUST be Serum.

•• Specimens may be stored on or off the clot for up to 16 hours at room temperature or up to 3 days at 2-8°C.If testing will be delayed more than 3 days, remove serum from the clot and store at -20°C or colder. Avoid more than 3 freeze/thaw cycles.

Reference for Retrospective Testing: Abbott Alinity Active-B12, kit insert March 2019
note:
Reference Interval:  25—165 pmol/L

Holotranscobalamin (HOLOTC) measures the biologically available fraction of Vitamin B12.

<25 pmol/L           Vitamin B12 deficient   

25-35 pmol/L        Borderline low B12. Suggest review of clinical information together with confirmatory laboratory tests. For Further information contact Haematology registrars on ext 63075.

>35 pmol/L           Vitamin B12 normal

Method: Abbott Alinity Active-B12

Reference Interval Alinity kit Insert Ref 09P2620, March 2019

Note: Active-B12 Reference Interval amended 18 March 2021

collection:
Specimen must not be exposed to air. Supply either a separate, full serum container or a venous or arterial specimen collected in a syringe as for Blood Gases. 
Mix well and deliver immediately.
Note: Syringes containing 125 USP units of heparin are unsuitable due to binding of ionised calcium.

This test may be of value when doubt exists about calcium status in the presence of hypoalbuminaemia and in acid/base disturbances.
Stasis must be avoided when taking blood as prolonged use of a torniquet gives falsely high values, as does haemolysis.

collection:
Add exactly 2.7 mL of blood & mix by inversion.Prothrombin activity is expressed as the International Normalised Ratio (INR).

Specimens cannot be analysed or re-analysed greater than 8 hours after collection.
note:
Reference Range: 0.9-1.3

Therapeutic Ranges:

Prophylaxis for atrial fibrillation                2.0-3.0

collection:
Add exactly 2.7 mL of blood & mix by inversion.Deliver to laboratory within 60 minutesWhen the collection is by vacuum tube,the coagulation tube should be collected second to avoid artefactual shortening of coagulation assays due to the trauma of venesection.  When syringes are used, have ready two plastic syringes. A butterfly needle may be used. Withdraw 5 mL blood into the first syringe and discard the syringe (or use it for other tests). With the second syringe, withdraw the required amount of blood for the coagulation tests. When blood is collected from an arterial line it is necessary to discard the first 20mL of blood to clear any heparin from the line before collecting the blood for coagulation tests.

This test is insensitive to therapeutic doses of Low Molecular Weight Heparin (see ANTI-Xa ASSAY and ANTICOAGULANT THERAPY CONTROL).

APTT may be artefactually shortened if the venesection is traumatic or artefactually prolonged if the tube is 'under-filled' or the patient has a raised haemoglobin/haematocrit.

Specimens cannot be analysed or re-analysed greater than 2 hours after collection.
note:
Reference Range:  26.0—38.0 sec

IV Heparin Therapeutic Range:  52-94 sec (in-house validation against heparin anti-Xa October 2014)

collection: AFP is useful in monitoring some testicular germ cell tumours and primary hepatocellular carcinoma. After treatment, e.g. orchidectomy, levels fall with a half-life of approximately 45 days. Values > 500 ug/L are virtually diagnostic of malignancy. However, 50% of all malignancies have values < 500 ug/L. AFP can also be raised in a variety of non-malignant liver disorders, where levels are usually < 100 ug/L.

collection: Serum preferred. Lithium Heparin and EDTA plasma acceptable.
note:
Aminoterminal peptide of type III procollagen (PIIINP) is produced in the processing of procollagen to mature collagen type III. This marker has been used to identify patients at increased risk of liver fibrosis who are exposed to large amounts of methotrexate (>1.5g total).

The cut-off level that is used to identify patients at increased risk is > 4.2 ug/L.

Note that this is well within the reference range as described by the company. The reference interval for adults (19 -65 years) was determined in over 200 healthy adults as 2.3 ug/L to 6.4 ug/L.

Reference values in children are significantly higher. Further note that this is the same assay that has been used in the clinical studies published (Maurice PDL et al. Monitoring patients on Methotrexate: hepatic fibrosis not seen in patients with normal serum assays of aminoterminal peptide of type III procollagen. Br J Dermatol 2005; 152:451 - 8, Kahn S et al. Use of amino terminal type III procollagen peptide (P3NP) assay in methotrexate therapy for psoriasis, Postgrad Med J 2006;82:353-354).

Ref. Range details supplied by A/Prof. Hans Schneider November 2008.

NOTE: This test NO longer available at Alfred Pathology Service

collection:
Do not use very fine needles or draw hard on syringes. There should be minimal stasis and no fist–clenching before or during blood collection.

Potassium levels are significantly raised by haemolysis, and by long delays before specimen separation (worse if specimen cooled).

Retrospective testing with 12 hours.

assay: Pro-Brain Natriuretic PeptideAlternative Names:NTBNPPro-BNPLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:NTBNPSpecimen Types:SerumPlasmaContainer Types:SSTLithium Heparin (with Gel)Adults Volume or Mass:4 mLMinimum/Paediatric Volume or Mass:4 mLTransport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room Temperature
note:
From 3 August 2020-  NTPro-BNP Assay performed on Abbott Alinity

Reference Intervals:

NTPro-BNP <125ng/L makes a diagnosis of congestive heart failure (CHF) very unlikely1 , while a NTPro-BNP >150ng/L is associated with increased 10 year mortality2.

Optimal sensitivity and specificity cut off for NTPro-BNP in CHF diagnosis in the ED was found with age-adjusted cut offs3,4

Age < 50            >450ng/L

Age 50 -75         >900ng/L

Age >75             >1800ng/L

1) Ponikowski P et al. 2016 ESC Guidelines for the diagnosis and treatment of acute and chronic heart failure.Eur J Heart Fail 2016;18(8):891-975.

2) Taylor CJ et al. The potential role of NT-proBNP in screening for and predicting prognosis in heart failure: a survival analysis. BMJ Open 2014;4:e004675

3) Januzzi JL et al. NT-proBNP testing for diagnosis and short-term prognosis in acute destabilized heart failure: an international pooled analysis of 1256 patients: the International Collaborative of NT-proBNP Study. Eur Heart J. 2006;27(3):330-337.

4) Januzzi JL Jr et al. N-Terminal Pro-B-Type Natriuretic Peptide in the Emergency Department: The ICON-RELOADED Study. J Am Coll Cardiol. 2018;71(11):1191-1200.4)

Levels correlate well with tumour bulk and clinical stage, but significant elevations have also been seen in benign prostatic hypertrophy.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureAdditional Notes:Reference Range:  

Age related Reference ranges introduced 3 Sept 2010

Males

0-30 days                  0.05 ug/L    

31 days - 7.99 years   <0.01 ug/L

8-17.99 years            <1.5 ug/L

18-29.99 years           0.2-2.0 ug/L

30-39.99 years           0.2-2.1ug/L

40-44.99 years           0.25-2.2 ug/L

45-49.99 years           0.25-2.5 ug/L

50-54.99 years           0.25-3.0 ug/L

55-59.99 years           0.3-3.5 ug/L

60-64.99 years           0.3-4.5 ug/L

65-69.99 years           0.3-5.5 ug/L

70-74.99 years           0.3-6.5 ug/L

75-79.99 years           0.3-7.5 ug/L

80-115 years              0.25-9.0 ug/L

 

Females                    <0.01 ug/L

Pregnancy                 <0.2 ug/L

Method used is Abbott Alinity (CMIA).

Ref: Sikaris KA, Caldwell G, “Age related reference intervals for the Architect PSA.” Clin Biochem Rev 2007:28:S33

If specimens are collected from a location external to Alfred Pathology, they should be spun and the plasma frozen at -80 C. Please note that freezing at -20 C is NOT sufficient and may cause cryo-activation of pro-renin leading to falsely high results.

Once frozen at -80 C, samples can be transferred to, or transported at, -20 C.
collection: Retrospective testing not possible.Endocrine consultation is required in planning renal vein sampling.
note:
Reference Interval:  4.4 - 46.1 mIU/L

Source: Diasorin Liaison kit insert 200/007-906,06-2016-04

ARR- aldosterone renin ratio

Aldosterone-Renin Ratio (ARR) is a screening test not a diagnostic test for primary hyperaldosteronism. As of 08/06/2017 Aldosterone and Renin are being performed on the Diasorin Liaison XL platform. Please note changed reference intervals.

An aldosterone-renin ratio cut-off of > 70 should prompt further investigation for primary hyperaldosteronism in the appropriate clinical setting. Lower cut-offs improve sensitivity with a loss in specificity whereas higher cut-offs are more specific for primary hyperaldosteronism (with a concomitant loss in sensitivity).

Reference: The Endocrine Society clinical practice guideline on primary hyperaldosteronism,  Funder JW, Carey RM, Mantero F, et al. J Clin Endocrinol Metab 101:1889-1916, 2016

Note: Renin is measured as direct renin mass (mIU/L) rather than plasma renin activity (µg/L/hr) previously. There is no conversion factor for the two assays. Compared to plasma renin activity, renin mass is reduced in high estrogen states (oral contraceptive pill) and increased in patients taking renin inhibitors.

assay: Folate SerumLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:SFOLSpecimen Types:SerumContainer Types:SSTTransport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Use Esky from SDMH or CGMC to Alfred
note:
Reference Range: >7.0 nmol/L

Method used is Abbott Alinity (CMIA).

This test is offered only in exceptional circumstances.

Audits performed at Alfred Health have demonstrated that routine folate testing has no clinical benefit.

If megaloblastic anaemia is suspected and B12 is normal, suggest folate replacement.

For queries, ring Haematology registrar on 63075.

assay:
Soluble Transferrin ReceptorAlternative Names:Transferrin Receptor IndexLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:STFRSpecimen Types:SerumContainer Types:SSTCollection & Request Instructions:Detects iron-deficient erythropoiesis. Not influenced by acute or chronic inflammatory states.

Please request Ferritin in addition to calculation of index.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room Temperature
collection:
Detects iron-deficient erythropoiesis. Not influenced by acute or chronic inflammatory states.

Please request Ferritin in addition to calculation of index.
container: Soluble Transferrin ReceptorAlternative Names:Transferrin Receptor IndexLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:STFRSpecimen Types:Serum
note:
Reference Intervals:

Male and Female (1-5 yrs)       2.5 - 6.0 mg/L

Male and Female (5 - 15 yrs)   2.2 - 5.5 mg/L

Males (16 to 99 yrs)                    2.2-5.0 mg/L 

Females (16-99yrs)                     1.9-4.4 mg/L

Elevated levels of sTFR are noted in patients with iron deficiency, even with concurrent inflammation. They can also be seen in conditions with increased red cell formation/ turnover. Some examples are haemolytic conditions, recent blood loss, erythropoiesis stimulating agents, myelodysplasia or inerited red cell disorders such as G6PD-deficiency or hereditary spherocytosis.

collection: Collect pre-doseRetrospective testing within 7 days
note:
Therapeutic Ranges (pre-dose):

  Heart Transplantation

  Levels < 6 months post-transplant:    10 - 15 ug/L

  Levels >/= 6  months post-transplant: 5 - 10 ug/L 


  LungTransplantation

  Levels < 12 months post-transplant:    9 - 14 ug/L

  Levels >/= 12 months post-transplant: 7 - 10 ug/L

  

 Bone Marrow Transplantation
  Levels post-transplant:                       5—10 ug/L

 

 Renal Transplantation - Trough levels

 (in high risk patients, higher levels may be targeted  

  on discussion with renal consultant)

  Levels < 3 months post-transplant:    5 - 10 ug/L

  Levels 3 - 6  months post-transplant: 4 - 8 ug/L

  Levels > 6 months post-transplant:   4 - 6 ug/L

 

 

 

Method: LCMSMS from 08 January 2010

note:
Reference Interval:

Source- Abbott Alinity i 2nd Generation Testosterone kit insert (Ref 07P68 June 2017). 

Adult Males:      8.0 - 30.0  nmol/L

Adult Females: 0.4 - 2.0  nmol/L

 

 

Studies show testosterone levels in women falling with age. This process starts before the menopause and continues further after the menopause (Yeap et al. JCEM 97: 408-415, 2012). In healthy older men testosterone levels also drop mildly with age (Yeap et al. JCEM 97: 4030-4039, 2012).

assay:
P1NPAlternative Names:Procollagen type 1 amino-terminal peptideLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:P1NPSpecimen Types:PlasmaSerumContainer Types:EDTA 6 mLSSTLithium Heparin (with Gel)Collection & Request Instructions:Marker of bone formation. Useful for monitoring effect of anti-resorptive therapy and patient compliance.

 

Note: For retrospective test requests;

Serum , K3-EDTA plasma and  Li-heparin plasma are stable for 24 hrs at 15 -25 C, 5 days at 2 - 8C,   6 months at -20C. Samples may be frozen and thawed up to 5 times without adverse effects.

K3-EDTA plasma is our preferred specimen.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room Temperature

assay:
Tricyclic Antidepressant ScreenLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:TCASpecimen Types:SerumPlasmaContainer Types:SSTLithium Heparin (with Gel)Collection & Request Instructions:Screening for Tricyclic Antidepressants in human serum or plasma

Tricyclics are widely used for the treatment of depression and also in the treatment of chronic pain.  Tricyclic overdoses are sometimes used to try to commit suicide.  In this setting, cardiac arrhythmia, respiratory depression and death may result.  Despite a change in the epidemiology of intentional antidepressant overdoses Amitriptyline and similar Tricyclics are continuing to be one of the major causes of death in intentional overdose (Sinyor M, Howlett A, Cheung AH, Schaffer A. Substances used in completed suicide by overdose in Toronto: an observational study of coroner's data. Can J Psychiatry. 2012 Mar;57(3):184-91, Gallagher LM, Kappatos D, Tisch C, Ellis PM. Suicide by poisoning in New Zealand--a toxicological analysis. N Z Med J. 2012 Sep 21;125(1362):15-25).  With levels greater than 500mg/L the incident of serious cardiac toxicity increases significantly (Simpson GM, Pi EH, White K. Plasma drug levels and clinical response to antidepressants. J Clin Psychiatry. 1983 May;44(5 Pt 2):27-34).

The Abbott Alinity Tricyclic Antidepressant assay (TCA) detects a number of tricyclics such as Amitriptyline, Chlorpromazine, Cyclobenzaprine, Desimipramine, Doxepin, Imipramine and Protriptyline. Different drugs are detected by this method to a varying degree. After consultation Clinical Biochemistry has decided that TCA results are reported as  Detected for TCA levels that are greater than 300mg/L (based on nortriptyline).  A Detected result in this assay indicates only the presence of a Tricyclic and does not necessarily correlate with the extent of physiological or psychological effects. If clinically indicated, Detected results should be confirmed by more specific methods such as HPLC or LC Tandem MS.

Hans SchneiderTransport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room TemperatureNote:   TCA screen is  QUALITATIVE  only.

Individual TCA levels are not measured at Alfred Pathology.

collection: Retrospective testing within 7 daysFrom 2/7/2013 Cardiac Troponin I is measured with the Abbott Architect high sensitvity assay with improved low end precision. The units have changed from ug/L to ng/L, giving troponin I values 1000-fold higher than previously. Gender specific 99th percentiles are <27ng/L for men and <17 ng/L for women. Elevated troponin I is indicative of myocardial injury but does not identify the aetiology. Higher troponin I values even below the 99th percentile are associated with worse long term (years) outcome.
container: Troponin IAlternative Names:TnILaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:TROPONINSpecimen Types:SerumPlasma
note:
Reference Range: Males     < 27 ng/L
                            Females < 17 ng/L

Elevated levels associated with cardiac disease are an independent predictor of mortality.

 

A persistent elevation of Troponin I which is not consistent with the clinical picture can be due to heterophile antibodies interference. Please contact the laboratory for further tests to exclude this interference.

collection:
Retrospective testing :

Sample stable for 24 hrs at 2-8C, 12 mths at -20C, Freeze only once.
note:
Assay performed on Roche Elecsys (ECLIA)
Reference Interval : <15  ng/L

Note: Change of units from 5/4/2017- ug/L to ng/L

Note: Preferred sample type is Serum. 

This assay is only available for Research/Trial purposes. 

Standard Troponin assay at Alfred Health is Troponin I only.

If a Troponin T is required for clinical purposes - consult Chemical Pathologist Prof Hans Schneider.

Note: Biotin supplementation may cause falsely low results due to interference with the Troponin T assay. If the patient is known to be taking Biotin, interpret results with caution and contact the Chemical Pathologist (03) 90763118 if further discussion is required.

assay:
TryptaseLaboratory:HaematologyTest Code:TRYPTASESpecimen Types:SerumContainer Types:SSTAdults Volume or Mass:10 mLMinimum/Paediatric Volume or Mass:2 mLCollection & Request Instructions:The sample should be collected between 15 minutes and 3 hours after the suspected anaphylactic event.

Increased levels of Tryptase can normally be detected up to 3 to 6 hours after the anaphylactic reaction. Levels return to normal within 12—14 hours after release.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:See Detailed InformationSeparated serum can be stored at 4 degrees C for 48 hours for transport between labs. For longer periods samples must be frozen and transported frozen.

container: 25-Hydroxyvitamin DAlternative Names:Vitamin DVitamin D3Vitamin D -25(OH)Laboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:25OHVITDSpecimen Types:PlasmaSerum
note:
Reference Intervals;

Vitamin D adequacy: > 50 nmol/L at the end of winter (level may need to be 10–20 nmol/L higher at the end of summer, to allow for seasonal decrease).

• Mild vitamin D deficiency: 30–49 nmol/L

• Moderate vitamin deficiency: 12.5–29 nmol/L

• Severe vitamin D deficiency: < 12.5 nmol/L

 

(Ref: Med J Aust 2012; 196 (11): 686-687)

Note: > 250 nmol/L can be associated with toxicity and hypercalcemia.

Test: GlucoseAlternative Names:Random Blood GlucoseFasting Blood Glucose
collection:
Fluoride Oxalate is the preferred sample where testing will be delayed and/or a diagnostic decision is required. For routine monitoring on inpatients serum is suitable.

Retrospective testing only available on  Fluoride Oxalate sample .
container: GlucoseAlternative Names:Random Blood GlucoseFasting Blood GlucoseLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:GL or GLFO or GLFOFSpecimen Types:PlasmaSerum
note:
Reference Intervals:
  Fasting:     3.5 - 6.0 mmol/L
  Random:   3.5 - 7.7  mmol/L

Relevant Ref. Intervals effective from 06/06/2013

 

A random glucose > 7.8 mmol/L in inpatients should trigger clinicians to follow the guideline for  “Blood Glucose Monitoring" (Fig 1) in Alfred Health PROMPT.

 

Comments for Glucose for Pathology Handbook

 

 

Blood glucose values vary normally throughout the day especially between pre- and post-prandial levels.  Normal fasting glucose levels are between 3.5 and 6.0 mmol/L, but levels between 5.5 and 6.0 mmol/L indicate an increased risk for diabetes especially for patients designated as high risk for diabetes: people of Aboriginal, Torres Strait Islander, Maori descent, Pacific Islander people, people from the Indian sub-continent, or of Chinese descent aged 35 and over, all people aged 45 or over who have either obesity or hypertension, all people aged 55 and over, and some others (see Joint Position Statement of RCPA and AACB 2008).  

 

Fasting Glucose Levels ≥ 6.1 to 6.9 mmol/L inclusive are defined as impaired fasting glucose and levels of 7 mmol/L and above define diabetes (if asymptomatic should be confirmed with second specimen). An abnormal level of glucose in the absence of diabetes needs to be repeated.

 

Impaired glucose tolerance (IGT, pre diabetes) is defined as values between 7.8 and 11.1 mmol/L at 2h after a 75g glucose load.  Random blood glucose levels ≥ 11.1 mmol/L ( or 2h after a 75g glucose load) on more than one occasion are diagnostic of diabetes.

Beyond the neonatal period hypoglycaemia is defined as glucose levels below 2.5 mmol/L.

Consensus Guidelines now also allow for HbA1c to be used for the diagnosis of Diabetes Mellitus, although it is currently not reimbursed by Medicare (Med J Aust 2012; 197:220-221).

Prof Hans Schneider: 19 August 2013

assay:
D-DimerLaboratory:HaematologyTest Code:DDSpecimen Types:PlasmaContainer Types:Sodium CitrateCollection & Request Instructions:Add exactly 2.7 mL of blood & mix by inversion.D-Dimer in Venous Thromboembolism (VTE)

Normal D-Dimer levels (<0.5 mcg/ml FEU.) essentially exclude VTE when the clinical index of suspicion for the VTE is low. However patients with normal D-Dimer levels, but in whom there is a moderate or high clinical suspicion of thrombosis, may warrant further investigations for VTE. Elevation of D-Dimer levels (>/=0.5 mcg/ml FEU.) occurs in some clinical circumstances in addition to VTE. These include liver disease, pregnancy and increasing age. If clinical features are suggestive of venous thrombosis or pulmonary embolism, further investigations are warranted.

 

D-Dimer in Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)

Markedly elevated D-Dimer levels ( >/ =10 mcg/ml FEU.) are associated with DIC. Serial measurements and interpretaion in conjunction with other coagulation assays (fibrinogen, APTT and PT- INR) are recommended to monitor DIC

Specimens cannot be analysed or re-analysed greater than 8 hours after collection.

 Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room Temperature

Test: Factor V Leiden MutationAlternative Names:FVLMFV LeidenLeiden MutationActivated Protein C Resistance Mutation Testing
collection:
For identification of carriers of inherited venous thrombophilia. General population screening and routine screening before prescribing oral contraceptives or hormone replacement therapy are not recommended. test should only be requested by a practioner skilled in genetic counselling of thrombophilia. The significance of a polymorphism in an affected individual is uncertain. Test is Factor -V-Leiden G1691A or R506Q.

PCR assay for detection of Factor V nucleotide substitution causing Activated Protein C Resistance.

assay:
Feto-Maternal HaemorrhageAlternative Names:FMHLaboratory:HaematologyTest Code:FMHSpecimen Types:BloodContainer Types:EDTA 3 mLAdults Volume or Mass:3 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Detects foetal cells in maternal circulation via flowcytometry.
Sample should ideally be collected within 2 hours of the sensitizing event and prior to adminsitration of  RhD immunoglobulin.
The test is only available 9-5 Mon- Fri as a routine test. For urgent testing (required within or after hours) the requesting doctor needs to contact the laboratory (63100) who will put them in contact with the appropriate Haematologist to authorise the test. Once authorised via this process staff will assay  urgently.
Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room Temperature

collection:
The treating HMO must obtain the patient's consent before conducting this test.
Section 120AC of the Health Act 1958 requires that 

    a competent patient who is tested; and 
    an incompetent patient at the time of testing who subsequently regains capacity, 

must  be counselled by a registered medical practitioner  
 
 
The person counselled must be provided with details of the test conducted, the reasons why the test was conducted, the results of the test and, if the test indicated the presence of an infectious disease, the effects of that disease on an infected person and the risk to public health of the disease. If needed, advice can be sought from the Infectious Diseases Unit at any time regarding counselling of such patients including the implications of positive tests.

The person counselled must be provided with details of the test conducted, the reasons why the test was conducted, the results of the test and, if the test indicated the presence of an infectious disease, the effects of that disease on an infected person and the risk to public health of the disease. If needed, advice can be sought from the Infectious Diseases Unit at any time regarding counselling of such patients including the implications of positive tests. 
 Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room Temperature
transport:
HIV SerologyLaboratory:MicrobiologyTest Code:HIVSpecimen Types:SerumContainer Types:SSTCollection & Request Instructions:The treating HMO must obtain the patient's consent before conducting this test.
Section 120AC of the Health Act 1958 requires that 

    a competent patient who is tested; and 
    an incompetent patient at the time of testing who subsequently regains capacity, 

must  be counselled by a registered medical practitioner  
 
 
The person counselled must be provided with details of the test conducted, the reasons why the test was conducted, the results of the test and, if the test indicated the presence of an infectious disease, the effects of that disease on an infected person and the risk to public health of the disease. If needed, advice can be sought from the Infectious Diseases Unit at any time regarding counselling of such patients including the implications of positive tests.

False positives may occur through dietary factors. The patient should not ingest any iron medications, or any food prepared from red meat, for three days prior to the test.

note:
Reference Intervals:

  pH:       7.35—7.45  
  pCO2:  35—45 mm Hg  
  pO2:     80—100 mm Hg  

  NaD:     135—145 mmol/L

  KD:       3.5—5.2 mmol/L

  Ca++: 1.11—1.28 mmol/L

  Cl:        95—110 mmol/L

  Bicc:    22—32 mmol/L

  Glu:     3.5—7.7 mmol/L

  Lact:     0.8—1.8 mmol/L

tHb(female): 113—159 g/L

tHb(male):     128—175 g/L

 sO2    :                   > 95%

 FCOHb:         <1.5%

 FMetHb:        <2% 

 BE:                  -3 - 3 mmol/L 

Measured at 37°C; correction for patient temperature is not routinely performed.

collection:
This screen is only reliable when urine is collected within 24 hrs of laxative ingestion.
The laxative screen is only able to detect stimulant laxatives such as bisacodyl, phenolphthalein, danthron and the naturally occurring anthraquinone glycosides.

collection:
Need 10mL of Blood and 3mL of Bone Marrow.

Specimens must be kept at room temperature and must be less than 48 hours old to be processed.

Specimens should be sent to the Haematology Laboratory on Mondays to Thursdays between 0900-1730 hrs. Outside these hours liase with the Haemtology Registrar on ext 63075 before collecting. Specimens need to go interstate and be processed on arrival at Royal Prince Alfred within 48 hours.

Due to the processing requirements specimen must be sent on arrival on day of collection or at latest next day (Monday to Thursdays only)

collection: These tests are of value prinicipally — a) in differentiation of the cause of low plasma sodium; b) to differentiate between pre-renal and renal failure in certain circumstances where oliguria is present; c)in acute disturbances of sodium and potassium homeostasis, as a guide to immediate therapy; d) to assess volume status.

assay:
Urine Drug ScreenAlternative Names:UDSDrug Screen UrineUDRSCLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:UDRSC or outside (OGCMS or UDRSO)Specimen Types:Urine randomContainer Types:Plain 70mL potAdults Volume or Mass:50 mLCollection & Request Instructions:Includes screening for Benzodiazepines, Barbiturates, Cannabinoids, Amphetamine Type Substances (Sympathomimetic Amines, Amphetamine and Amphetamine type substances), Opiates & Cocaine Metabolites plus a general qualitative UPLC/QTof (or GCMS screen).

In addition to the above the urine drug screen is able to screen for a range of NSAIDs, diuretics, methadone and buprenorphine. Contact the Clinical Biochemistry drug laboratory for further information.

Further Information on Drug Identifcation.

 Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room Temperature

collection:
Pre and Post vaccination sera required. Send second serum approximately 6 weeks post vaccination.

The pre serum will be stored for a maximum of 6 months awaiting the post serum.

Instruct patients to return to the same collection centre so that specimen matching can occur.

Serum from splenectomy patients will be sent on receipt. Indicate clearly on the request slip.

container: Nucleophosmin (NPM1) Gene MutationAlternative Names:NPM1 Gene MutationLaboratory:Human MolecularTest Code:MH FLT3/NPM1 FASpecimen Types:BloodBone Marrow
note:
PLEASE NOTE - this is a screening test for use at diagnosis.

The NPM1 screening test is multiplexed with FLT3 FA (fragment analysis) testing.

This is not the correct test for NPM1-MRD (minimal residual disease).

Test: Prothrombin G20210A MutationAlternative Names:Prothrombin GenePT GeneG20210APTGM
collection: For identification of carriers of inherited venous thrombophilia. General population screening and routine screening before prescribing oral contraceptives or hormone replacement therapy are not recommended. Test should only be requested by a practioner skilled in genetic counselling of thrombophilia. The significance of a polymorphism in an unaffected individual is uncertain.

Test: CMV Viral LoadAlternative Names:Cytomegalovirus Viral Load
assay:
CMV Viral LoadAlternative Names:Cytomegalovirus Viral LoadLaboratory:MicrobiologyTest Code:CMVVILOSpecimen Types:BloodContainer Types:EDTA 10 mLCollection & Request Instructions:A separate unopened EDTA blood tube is required.
Collect in the morning to allow for the lengthy preparation that must occur on the same day. Specimen must be less than 24 hours old.
A maximum of  1 CMV viral load test per sample type will be performed on any patient in a one week period. 
Requests for urgent or more frequent testing must be approved by the Microbiology Unit Head. Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room Temperature

Test: Haemophilus Influenzae Type b SerologyAlternative Names:HIB Serology
collection:
Pre and Post vaccination sera recommended. Send second serum approximately 6 weeks post vaccination.

Instruct patients to return to the same collection centre so that specimen matching can occur.

Pre samples are stored for a maximum of 6 months.

Single samples only sent on request.

collection:
Platelet Aggregation Studies require approval with the Haematology Laboratory prior to collection. Please call ext 63109 before proceeding

Test by appointment only, following consultation with laboratory haematology medical staff. Assay only valid if platelet count is adequate( >100 x 10 9/L) in most cases. Request should include information on bleeding history and medication.

Specimens cannot be analysed or re-analysed greater than 4 hours after collection.

2.7 mL of blood is drawn into six (6) sodium citrate vacuum tubes.  These are kept at room temperature and sent to the laboratory asap.

collection:
Spinal tap should be performed at least 12hrs following suspected SAH.

Send to laboratory Urgently - must be spun within 1hr.

Tube 4 is the preferred tube.

Cover sample with foil to protect from light.
container: CSF Xanthochromia ScreenAlternative Names:CSF BilirubinXanthochromiaLaboratory:Clinical BiochemistryTest Code:CSXANSpecimen Types:Cerebrospinal Fluid
note:
Please note - if the sample is received after being unprotected from light this can lead to a decrease in bilirubin and a false negative result for Xanthochromia. Please interpret with this in mind and in the context of other tests and clinical history.

Reference: Foroughi M, Parikh D, Wassell J, Hatfield R. Influence of light and time on bilirubin degradation in CSF spectrophotometry for subarachnoid haemorrhage. Br J Neurosurg. 2010 Aug;24(4):401-4”

Test: CSF Oligoclonal BandsAlternative Names:Oligoclonal IgG (CSF)IgG/Albumin ratio CSFIsoelectric Focussing CSF
collection:
Serum sample must be collected at the same time for interpretation of results.
Retrospective testing with 7 days.
note: In several diseases of the central nervous system (multiple sclerosis and certain chronic infectious diseases such as sub–acute sclerosing pan–encephalitis and neurosyphilis) there are quantitative and qualitative alterations in immunoglobulins synthesised inside the blood–brain barrier. A relative increase in IgG in CSF, compared with serum, and the existence of oligoclonal bands (discrete bands representing IgG molecules of restricted heterogeneity) in CSF, which do not exist in serum at that time, provide strong evidence for the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis.

Note: For Trials refer to senior scientist.

 

Sample Stability

Multiple Freeze thaw cycles should be avoided.

Urine specimens may be stored up to 14 days at 2-8C.

Urine specimens can be stored up to 30 days at -10C or colder.

 Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room Temperature

assay:
Blood CulturesLaboratory:MicrobiologyTest Code:BL CSpecimen Types:BloodContainer Types:Blood Culture BottlesAdults Volume or Mass:10 mLMinimum/Paediatric Volume or Mass:4 mLCollection & Request Instructions:1. Collect blood cultures prior to commencement of antibiotic therapy.

2. Remove plastic flip top from culture bottle and disinfect with an alcohol pad or equivalent. This is important because the bottle septum is not sterile.

3.  Adult: 10mL of blood per bottle

  Paediatric: 4 mL of blood per bottle.

Line demarcations on the bottle label should be used to assist in estimating the sample volume.

4. Do not use of blunt needles or coring devices to puncture the stopper. These prevent sealing of the inoculation hole, leading to aeration or allowing the sample to leak.

5. The barcode labels on the bottle are for laboratory use ONLY. Do not remove or obscure the peel-off stickers.Transport Instructions between Sites and/or Laboratories:Room Temperature
collection:
1. Collect blood cultures prior to commencement of antibiotic therapy.

2. Remove plastic flip top from culture bottle and disinfect with an alcohol pad or equivalent. This is important because the bottle septum is not sterile.

3.  Adult: 10mL of blood per bottle

  Paediatric: 4 mL of blood per bottle.

Line demarcations on the bottle label should be used to assist in estimating the sample volume.

4. Do not use of blunt needles or coring devices to puncture the stopper. These prevent sealing of the inoculation hole, leading to aeration or allowing the sample to leak.

5. The barcode labels on the bottle are for laboratory use ONLY. Do not remove or obscure the peel-off stickers.
note:
Green top aerobic bottle

Orange top anaerobic bottle

Yellow top paediatric bottle

Cultures are incubated for 5 days. A negative report is issued after 48 hours. All positive blood culture Gram stains are phoned through to the Doctor responsible for patient care.

Test: Catheter Tip CultureAlternative Names:Intravenous catheter tip culture
collection:
With sterile scissors, cut off the terminal 5cm of the tip into a dry sterile container.
1. Clearly state the type of tip to be cultured.
 2. Urinary catheter tips will not be cultured, as misleading results are frequent. Intravenous catheter tips should be cultured only when the catheter is suspected to be the cause of sepsis.
3. A semi-quantitative count of organisms is made following culture to help distinguish contamination from infection.

Test: CSF Microscopy & CultureAlternative Names:Cerebrospinal Fluid MC&S
collection:
1. Out-of-hours: Notify on-call staff via Alfred switchboard if microscopy and culture required ( not usually indicated if CSF is clear macroscopically).
2.  A Gram stain is performed on any CSF with a raised white cell count (> 5 polymorphs x 106/L). 
3. Special tests are available on specific request. See individual test listings.
note:
Reference Ranges:
RBC                        0  x 10^6/L
Lymphocytes       < 5 x 10^6/L
Other WBC             0  x 10^6/L

Test: Faeces CultureAlternative Names:Clostridium difficile cultureCampylobacter cultureSalmonella cultureShigella culture
collection:
Collection KitAdults Volume or Mass:10 g Investigations for Salmonella, Shigella and Campylobacter are restricted to Outpatients and patients hospitalised for less than 4 days.

Only one (1) faecal sample is required. Collect 10g of faeces into each container.

Culture for Clostridium difficile is performed only on loose or watery stools.

Relevant clinical notes are essential. A history of recent overseas travel must be documented on the request slip.

Rectal swabs are unsuitable unless the patient is in ICU. For further information, contact the Microbiology Registrar.
